They all live in the Bagadadji neighborhood of Ségou (the fourth administrative region of Mali). They met each other through neighborhood, family, and marriage connections and from their businesses in the village. They run small seasoning, clothing, and food-serving businesses. With the goal of increasing their business funds, the group members decided to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso and are on their fourth group loan. Mrs. Jeanne Tanti (the woman standing to the far right in the photo) is a big seller of seasonings in the neighborhood and its surrounding areas. She plans to use her loan to buy a large quantity of all kinds of seasonings in Ségou. The sales are made for cash and often for credit from home and at the market to a mixed clientele. Mrs. Jeanne Tanti hopes to earn an average monthly profit of 26,000 FCFA with this loan, which will be used for the small needs of her children and equally to increase her business funds. She hopes to continue the collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso.

loans.use: to buy seasonings

loans.name: Okhirmo

texts.ru:
Охирмо искуссная и умелая ткачиха, проживаяющая в районе Рудаки. Ей 54 года. Она работает в текстиле около полгода и занимается там тканием ковровых изделий. Охирмо еще подрабатывает за счет продажи косметики и парфюмерии известных косметических компаний. Она активня и очень деятельная женщина.
Охирмо замужем и имеет двух дочерей и сына. Муж и сын предоставляют услуги по ремонту домов. Целью запрашиваемого кредита является расширение ее торговой деятельности. Охирмо хочет приобрести широкий ассортимент косметики и парфюмерии, так как приближается большой праздник и все будут делать друг другу подарки. Поэтому Охирмо надеется за счет этого увеличить доходность своего маленького торгового бизнеса.
texts.en:
Okhirmo is a skillful and smart weaver, living in the Rudaki region. She is 54 years old. She has worked with textile for around half a year and is engaged in the production of rugs. Okhirmo also earns money through selling cosmetics and perfumes of well-known brands. She is an active and enterprising woman. 

Okhirmo is married and has two daughters and one son. Her husband and son provide a carpenter service for renovating houses. The aim of the requested loan is to expand her retail business. Okhirmo would like to purchase a wide assortment of cosmetics and perfumes, as the great holiday is close and everyone will give each other presents. Okhirmo hopes to increase the income from her small retail business from this.

loans.use: to purchase cosmetics and perfumes to sell

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les sept femmes du groupe Danaya vivent toutes dans des familles nucléaires. Elles ont en moyenne 43 ans et 3 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le quartier Missira de Ségou (4ème Région administrative de la République du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté, mariage et de leurs activités génératrices de revenu dans le quartier. Elles font le petit commerce d’habillement, grains, condiment et de la restauration. Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur  6eme cycle du prêt solidaire.
 Madame Rokia (la 3eme femme debout de la droite vers la gauche dans la photo) est une grande vendeuse de pagne wax dans le quartier  et ses environnants. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 11 pièces de pagne wax à Ségou. La vente se fait au comptant et souvent à crédit à la maison, dans le marché à  une clientèle mixte.
 Madame Rokia i espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen  de 42 000FCFA avec ce prêt, qui sera utilisé pour des petits besoins de ses enfants et augmenter également  son fonds de commerce. Elle espère continuer la collaboration  avec Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en: The seven women of the Danaya group all live in nuclear families. They are on average 43 years old and have on average three children. They all live in the Missira neighborhood of Ségou (the fourth administrative region of Mali). They met each other through neighborhood, family, and marriage connections and from their businesses in the village. They run small clothing, seed, seasoning and food-serving businesses. With the goal of increasing their business funds, the group members decided to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso and are on their sixth group loan. Mrs. Rokia (the third woman standing from the right in the photo) is a big seller of pagne wax (traditional wraparounds) in the neighborhood and its surrounding areas. She plans to use her loan to buy 11 pieces of pagne wax in Ségou. The sales are made for cash and often for credit from home and at the market to a mixed clientele. Mrs. Rokia hopes to earn an average monthly profit of 42,000 FCFA with this loan, which will be used for the small needs of her children and equally to increase her business funds. She hopes to continue the collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso.

loans.use: to buy pagne wax (traditional wraparounds)

loans.name: Labanko Group

texts.fr:
Les neuf  femmes du groupe Labanko vivent toutes dans des familles nucléaires. Elles ont en moyenne 45 ans et 5 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le quartier Bagadadji de Ségou (4ème Région administrative de la République du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté, mariage et de leurs activités génératrices de revenu dans le quartier. Elles font le petit commerce de restauration, condiment, grains de riz et d’habillement. Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur  1er cycle du prêt solidaire.
 Madame Tata   Tenin  (la 3eme femme debout de la droite vers la gauche dans la photo) est une grande restauratrice dans le quartier Bagadadji de Ségou et ses environnants. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 2 sacs d’haricot à Ségou. La vente se fait au comptant et souvent à crédit à la maison, dans le marché à  une clientèle mixte.
 Madame Tata Tenin  espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen  de 20 000FCFA avec ce prêt, qui sera utilisé pour des petits besoins de ses enfants et augmenter également  son fonds de commerce. Elle espère continuer la collaboration  avec Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en: The nine women of the Labanko group all live in nuclear families. They are on average 45 years old and have on average five children. They all live in the Bagadadji neighborhood of Ségou (the fourth administrative region of Mali). They met each other through neighborhood, family, and marriage connections and from their businesses in the village. They run small food-serving, seasoning, rice seed, and clothing businesses. With the goal of increasing their business funds, the group members decided to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso and are on their first group loan. Mrs. Tata Tenin (third woman standing from the right in the photo) is a big restaurateur in the Bagadadji neighborhood in Ségou and its surrounding areas. She plans to use her loan to buy two sacks of beans in Ségou. The sales are made for cash and often for credit from home and at the market to a mixed clientele. Mrs. Tata  Tenin hopes to earn an average monthly profit of 20,000 FCFA with this loan, which will be used for the small needs of her children and equally to increase her business funds. She hopes to continue the collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso.

loans.use: to buy bean seeds for food service

loans.name: Nurzhamal

texts.ru: Нуржамал, 28 лет, замужем, есть 2 дочери. У Нуржамал среднее образование, с 2010 года она занимается сельским хозяйством. У нее есть участок мерою 0,70 ГА, где Нуржамал выращивает кукурузу и пшеницу. Ежемесячный доход Нуржамал составляет около 5,000 сом (KGS). Она обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 10,000 сом (KGS) на вспашку земли и покупку минеральных удобрений, чтобы выращивать экологически чистые культуры. Доходы от ведения бизнеса Нуржамал планирует вкладывать в дальнейшее развитие ее бизнеса, чтобы иметь возможность воспитать и достойно обучить своих дочерей.
texts.en:
Nurzhamal is 28 years old, married and has two daughters. Nurzhamal has secondary education. Since 2010 she has worked with agriculture. She owns a plot of land of 0.70 hectares, where she grows sweet corn and wheat. The monthly income is around 5,000 som (KGS).

Nurzhamal turned to the bank "Bai Tushum" for a loan in the amount of 10,000 som (KGS) to process the land and purchase mineral fertilizers, in order to grow ecological crops. She plans to invest the income from her business in further expanding it, in order to have the possibility to raise and educate her daughters adequately.

loans.use: to cultivate her land and purchase fertilizers in order to grow ecological corn and wheat

loans.name: Cinia Adilene

texts.es:
Cinia, vende lácteos y refrescos, vive con su esposo de 29 años de edad y una hija de 2 años de edad, junto a su esposo atienden  el negocio y es así como obtienen ingresos para subsistir, lo tiene ubicado en el mercado municipal y tiene más de 2 años de haberlo fundado.
Con el capital tendrá recursos económicos para comprar quesos, crema, quesillos, requesón y cuajada, incrementará la mercadería para la temporada, lo que le permitirá seguir cubriendo las necesidades de sus clientes y mejorando su situación económica.
Sus sueños son establecer mejor su negocio, trabajar para que sea más competitivo y rentable, de esa forma dar lo mejor a su familia.
texts.en: Cinia sells milk products and soft drinks and lives with her 29-year-old husband and 2-year-old daughter. She and her husband work in their business and this is how they earn their income which they live off of. They have had the store for two years and it is located in the town market. With the loan money, they will have the resources to buy cheese, cream, soft cheese, cottage cheese, and curd, increasing their merchandise for the season. This will allow them to continue meeting customers' needs and improving their economic situation. Their dream is to better establish their business and work towards a more competitive and profitable business so that they can give the best to their family.

loans.use: to buy cheese, cream, soft cheese, cottage cheese, and curd, increasing their merchandise for the season

loans.name: Jose Vidal

texts.es:
José, tiene la necesidad de un nuevo préstamo para comprar semilla, fertilizantes y abono, para preparar la tierra en la que sembrará maíz, tendrá oportunidad de seguir mejorando su negocio.
La ayuda del préstamo anterior ha sido de beneficio para incrementar la productividad de granos básicos, brinda mejor alimentación a su familia y vestuario.
texts.en: José needs a new loan to buy seeds, fertilizers, and compost to prepare the land where he will plant corn. This way he will have the opportunity to continue improving his business. Assistance from previous loans has been beneficial for increasing the productivity of staple grains, and providing better nutrition and clothing for his family.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers, and compost to prepare the land where he will plant corn.

loans.name: Khurma

texts.ru: Хурме 31 год. Она проживает на районе Пяндж. Хурма жена и мать. Раньше в семье работал один муж. Ему было нелегко обеспечить детей и жену одному. Хурма не могла ему помочь, из-за того что дети были маленькими она не могла устроиться на работу. Дети немножко подросли, и Хурма вышла на работу. Она занимается продажей детской одежды, игрушек, тканей и много разных товаров. Уже 2 года Хурма продвигает торговую деятельность. Сейчас она планирует расширить бизнес и увеличить доход. Для этого ей необходимо увеличить товарооборот, то есть купить и привести новый товар для продажи. Чтобы реализовать план ей не хватает средств, и она обратилась за кредитом.
texts.en:
Khurma is 31 years old. She lives in the Pyandj region. Khurma is a wife and a mother. Earlier only her husband worked. He had a difficult time supporting the children and his wife alone. Khurma was not able to help, because the children were small and she could not get a job. 

Now the children are a little older, and Khurma started to work. She sells children's items, toys, fabric and scarves and many other goods. She has had the retail business for two years already. 

Currently Khurma is planning to expand it and increase the income. To do this, she needs to increase the turnover, through purchasing and bringing in new goods to sell. She does not have enough money in order to realize her plan, and applied for a loan.

loans.use: to purchase children's items, toys, fabric, scarves

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Caroline is 40 years old, married to Elijah, and they are blessed with seven school-going children. For the past one year she has been buying and selling energy saving Jikos to the community, and earns KES. 5,000 which she uses to support her family.

She has applied for a first loan of KES. 10,000 with Vision Fund Kenya, and intends to use the entire loan to buy energy saving Jikos t sell at a profit. She plans to use the anticipate profit to plow back into her business.

In future Caroline hopes to grow her business and be prosperous.

loans.use: to buy more energy saving Jikos

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Hello world! Meet Lucy, a 40-year-old widow from Central province of Kenya. Lucy does mixed-farming on her late husband's 1.5 acre land. Her happy marriage life that lasted for 15 years was cut short by her husband's death. Since then, she has been forced to take up all the responsibility of feeding and looking after their 2 children, aged 6 and 14. 

In order for her to maintain her family's livelihood, she is determined to grow her income through leveraging the farm business and using the money to acquire more income-generating assets. It is for this reason that she is turning to Kiva lenders to seek a loan investment to purchase more heads of poultry. With more chickens, she will increase the quantity of eggs produced for sale. Her major strength that almost guarantees her success is the 20 years experience she has in this business.  

She is going to use the increased income to pay for the family's basic needs and school fees. She is banking so much on her children and she is investing on that through the money she is putting in tuition.

loans.use: to purchase heads of poultry

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a generator to be used in irrigation

loans.name: Bernard

texts.en:
Bernard is a married man. He has four children. He describes himself to be determined. He operates a carpentry where he makes furniture. He has been involved in this business for three years. His business is located in a vibrant area, and his primary customers are individuals. He describes his biggest business challenge to be lack of working capital. 

He will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more stock of carpentry materials. 

He hopes that in the future, he will own an exhibition shop. This is his first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of carpentry materials

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia is a married woman. She has one child. She describes herself to be capable and promising. She operates a retail business where she sells motor vehicle spare parts. She has been involved in this business for two years. Her business is located in a good area, and her primary customers are of all types. She describes her biggest business challenge to be a lack of working capital. 

She will use the Kes 10,000 loan to buy more stock of spare parts. Her business goal is to be prosperous within five years.

loans.use: to buy more stock of spare parts

loans.name: Duke

texts.en:
Duke is a married man. He has two children. He describes himself to be industrious and committed. He operates a farm where he keeps dairy cows and also grows crops. He has been involved in this business for four years. His business is located in a good area, and his primary customers are individuals. 

He will use the Kes 10,000 loan to buy farm inputs like feed and fertilizer. 

His business goal is to have a successful business within five years. This is his second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: buy farm inputs like feed and fertilizer

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 44 years. She is married and together with her spouse they have been blessed with six children.

Elizabeth runs a hotel, a business she has done for the last 20 years, earning a monthly income of Kshs. 54,000. 

Elizabeth has requested for her third loan with VisionFund Kenya of Kshs. 45,000, which she will use to add stock of dried foodstuffs to be cooked in the hotel. Such include cereals like rice, beans, green-grams, as well as baking flour.

With the anticipated profits, Elizabeth will be able to plow back the money into her business.

Her hope and dream for the future is to keep on expanding her business.

loans.use: to buy dried foodstuff

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy cattle for selling.

loans.name: Al-Naseem Group

texts.en:
This group is called Al-Naseem. It consists of four women from Sana'a city, Yemen. They applied for a loan of 170,000 YER from AMB.

Samah is the leader of the group, a married woman with 27 years old and a mother of two children. She works as a dressmaker inside her house, and earns a small amount of money because she doesn't have a lot of customers and her husband is an immigrant outside of the country. She doesn't have a TV inside the house, and this thing makes her feels inconvenienced also her children feel of the same condition. All the members of the family hope to watch some programs on TV when they finished their work. 

Samah's income is not enough to purchase it. For this reason, she applied for a loan of 50,000 YER from AMB in order to purchase a TV for the house.

Samah hopes to start her own business opening a small grocery in her area where she lives.

loans.use: To purchase a TV for the house.

loans.name: Iris

texts.es: Iris is divorced and she lives in her own house. She is a crafstwoman and she makes invitation cards and christmas cards She is been in this business since 4 years and she has her workshop at her house Iris is mother of two the oldest one is 7 years old and the second one is 4. Iris needs a loan to buy paper, paperboard, glue and ornaments to make more cards Iris is the only one at her home that makes money so she will appreciate a lot the help you can give her In the picture Iris appears with one of her cards
texts.en: Iris is divorced and she lives in her own house. She is a mother of two children, 4 and 7 years old. Iris is a crafstwoman who makes invitation cards and Christmas cards She is been in this business for 4 years and has her workshop in her house. Iris needs a loan to buy paper, paperboard, glue and ornaments to make more cards. She is the only income earner in her home so she will greatly appreciate the help you can give her. Iris appears in the photo with one of her cards.

loans.use: to buy paper, paperboard, glue and ornaments

loans.name: Zef

texts.en: Zef has been photographed with Ardenis, his son, for whom he is requesting this loan. Ardenis has been pursuing a masters degree in computer science and this will be his last year.

loans.use: to pay for his son's master's degree and other schooling-related fees

loans.name: Musa

texts.en: Musa is a Babban Gona maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Musa would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, in order to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Musa can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest time. When asked about his goals, Musa expressed a desire to use the extra income to provide his family with food and clothing, and in the long run, become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest time.

loans.name: Halladu

texts.en: Halladu is a maize farmer from Barangwaje village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Halladu would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to provide for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Halladu can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Halladu, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to provide food and clothing for his family, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Shaitu

texts.en: Shaitu is a maize farmer from Barangwaje village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Shaitu would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to provide for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Shaitu can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Shaitu, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to provide food and clothing for his family, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Sylvain

texts.en:
Sylvain, 27 years old, is not married. He is a farmer who has been farming for 5 years. Sylvain would like to use the loan from Kiva to buy more fertilizers to grow maize to sell. The profits from the business will be used to buy food for home consumption.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers  to grow maize to sell

loans.name: Jean Pierre

texts.en:
Jean Pierre, 27 years old, is not married. He is a farmer who has been farming for 7 years. Jean Pierre would like to use the loan from Kiva to buy more fertilizers to grow maize to sell. The profits from the business will be used to buy food for home consumption.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers to grow maize to sell

loans.name: Innocent

texts.en:
Innocent, 42 years old, is married and has 3 children aged between 8 and 15 years, all going to school. He is a farmer who has been farming for 20 years. Innocent would like to use the loan from Kiva to buy more fertilizers to grow maize to sell. The profits from the business will be used to buy food for home consumption.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers to grow maize to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to service his motorcycle.

loans.name: Jujuna

texts.en:
Jujuna is a 29-year-old woman from the Chakvi borough. She has a husband, a school-aged son and a little daughter. The only source of income for this 4-member family is Jujuna's husband's job; he works as a taskmaster and generates 400 GEL. The income is really insufficient for the family and they find it hard to tackle their financial difficulties. 

Jujuna has a great desire to do her part for the family's welfare and to be involved in her own business. She requested a loan but her application was rejected several times for not having enough income or business experience. Jujuna's loan request was approved by the start up program, a joint initiative of Kiva and Credo, which gives people a chance to start or re-start businesses. Jujuna plans to purchase clothing stock and other accessories for babies and start local sales. She will sell products from her house and will be able to generate her own income. The loan will greatly assist Jujuna and her family, enabling them to cover daily costs and improve their living conditions. They await your help.

loans.use: to generate her own income and start selling babies' clothing

loans.name: Yusuf

texts.en:
Yusufu is a 22-year-old married man who deals in a kitchen ware business, and works 7 days a week and 6 hours a day. He has been in this business since 2012. His business is located in Kyotera town, and he usually sells his goods to people around the town and surrounding areas. He was motivated to start the business by the fact that it was his area of expertise.

He hopes to use the loan to buy more kitchen wares for his business. His hope and dream are to construct a good house. However, he faces a challenge of limited capital and high transport costs, which affects his operations. He is described as an honest and hardworking man in business.

loans.use: To buy kitchen ware to sell

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.en:
This member belongs to the El Almanecer [Sunrise] Communal Bank, and is still running the two businesses that she started long ago: selling quail eggs and earrings. Both ventures are going well thanks to the diligent effort that the member dedicates to her work each day. She is a responsible and industrious person who wants to keep operating the businesses that allow her to support her family. 

The member is applying for a loan for the purchase of quail eggs and earrings. and is grateful for the loan and committed to making full payments.

loans.use: for the purchase of quail eggs and earrings.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to connect to Haiti's first pre-pay microgrid

loans.name: Saminu

texts.en:
Saminu is a maize farmer from Makera village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Saminu would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Saminu can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

Saminu, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to provide food and clothing for his family, and hopes to make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: To buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Lado

texts.en: Lado is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Lado joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Shitu, Hafisu and Zabura.  Before he became a Babban Gona member, Lado would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to provide for his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Lado can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Lado spoke of his  ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to ensure his children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to pay for his children's school fees and uniforms, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Amadu

texts.en: Amadu is a Babban Gona maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Amadu would have had to sell his  maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Amadu can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest time. When asked about his goals, Amadu expressed a desire to use the extra income to provide his family with food and clothing, and in the long run, to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest time.

loans.name: Bako Nuhu

texts.en: Bako Nuhu is a maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Bako Nuhu would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to provide for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Bako Nuhu can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Like other Babban Gona members, Bako Nuhu is looking to earn a better income to provide more food and clothing for his family, and hopes to make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia has a retail shop in Eldoret town, and has been running this business for two years now. She is 35 years old, married, and together with her spouse they have been blessed with four children. 

She will use this loan to buy more stock of goods such as maize flour, rice, salt, and cooking oil to sell. She will use the anticipated profits to provide for her family's needs, such as clothes and food. 

This is her first loan term from VisionFund Kenya, and in the future she hopes to have a prosperous business and live an enjoyable life with her family.

loans.use: To buy more stock of goods

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 44 years old. He is married with one child who is 20 years old, and goes to school. He is a farmer and has been farming for 14 years now. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to buy more fertilizers of maize for sale. The profits from the business will be used to buy food for home consumptions.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more maize fertilizers for sale.

loans.name: Maguli

texts.en:
Maguli, a 66-year-old woman from Kutaisi, lives and solely takes care of her two grandchildren, both school-aged. Their only source of existence is Maguli's pension of 150 GEL, which is hardly enough to even cover basic needs. According to the above mentioned situation, the family lives under the poverty line and needs financial support to live in better conditions.

Maguli has requested a Credo loan to start up a trading business. Her loan request was approved in the framework of a joint initiative by Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions for the country's poor people, who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. 

Maguli will purchase stock of various kinds of clothing and bags to sell at the local market. She is a really motivated and hardworking person with a great desire to ensure her grandchildren with good living conditions and education for progressing in life. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva startup loan, will significantly increase the family's income and the family members will be able to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to start a retail clothing business

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Ali would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Ali can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest.

 Like other Babban Gona members, Ali is looking  to earn a better income to provide more food and clothing for his family, and hopes to make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: To buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en: Robert is a hardworking married man living in Kyenjojo, Uganda with his three children aged 1, 3 and 6 years. He works as a shoe seller and he also engages in farming. His major business problems include his customers' bad debts and low turn-up of customers. He has a personal goal of building a permanent house and having a happy family. This is why Robert is requesting the loan to buy more shoes to sell.

loans.use: to buy more shoes to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase tailoring materials

loans.name: Millicent

texts.en:
Millicent is a married woman. She describes herself to be God-fearing. She operates a retail business where she sells sugar. She has been involved in this business for five years. Her business is located in a good area, and her primary customers are the general public. She describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of enough working capital. 

She will use the Kes 10,000 loan to buy more stock of sugar. 

This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of sugar

loans.name: Molly

texts.en:
Molly is a married woman. She has five children, with ages ranging from 3 years to 13 years. She describes herself to be dedicated. She operates a retail business where she sells tomatoes, onions, and cereals. She has been involved in this business for five years. Her business is located in a viable location, and her primary customers are the general public. She describes her biggest business challenge to be transportation and storage costs. 

She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more stock of cereals. 

Her business goal is to be able to sell in wholesale within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will be successful in business. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of cereals

loans.name: Lawal

texts.en: Lawal is a maize farmer from Bazana I village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Lawal would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest time, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Lawal can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest time. Lawal, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to provide food and clothing for his family, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest time.

loans.name: Kabasanja Bagambakamu Group

texts.en:
Scola is a member of Kabasanja Bagambakamu, where members guarantee each other. She is aged 48, with five children living in Fort Portal, Uganda. She sells mairungi, a local crop grown in her area, and at the same time owns a retail shop and a tea room that adds more income for her. She faces challenges of inadequate capital, however, she has hopes of educating all her children to higher levels of learning. 

Scola needs a loan to buy mairungi for selling.

loans.use: to buy mairungi for selling

loans.name: Bernard

texts.en:
Bernard, 74, runs a small farm in the Chuka area of Kenya. To run his business, he counts himself lucky to get the necessary support from his wife of 40 years, Susana. The couple owns an 11 acre farm that is home to 3 cows, 7 pigs and 30 heads of poultry. Also, there is presence of hundreds of trees and crops on the farm. 

Having been in the business for more than four decades, Bernard understands the importance of proper animal care. It is for this reason that he is seeking a KES 20,000 loan from Kiva lenders to pay for animal care services for his pigs. 

Your investment will help Bernard pay for animal care services that will save him future costs on health care and also increase his income because the farm animals will be more productive in better animal welfare. This way, Benard's livelihood will be improved without him having to be dependent on his children, who are actively looking after their own families.

loans.use: to pay for animal care services

loans.name: Halimah

texts.en:
Halima is a resident of Lukuli Boston a city suburb, where she lives with her husband and four children. She is a first time borrower with Ugafode Micro Finance Ltd, and deals in a transport business, mainly taxi. She operates two taxis in Kampala City. 

She has requested a loan of UGX.4,000,000 to help her repair one of her taxis, and she is grateful to KIVA and Ugafode Microfinance (MDI) LTD for the financial support provided.

loans.use: to repair her taxi

loans.name: Yosia

texts.en:
Yosia is a 43-year-old married man with four children in Kyenjojo, Uganda. He generates income from goat-rearing, alongside selling cattle for eight years. He has a challenge of inadequate capital to meet the customers’ demand for meat during peak periods like Christmas. 

Yosia has a personal goal of buying a motorcycle and educating his children. Therefore, he wants a loan to buy cattle for fattening and later to sell.

loans.use: to buy cattle for fattening and later to sell.

loans.name: Vlash

texts.en:
Vlash is in the photograph with his wife, Dila, married parents of three in their early 20's; they are rural people and their only activity, just like the majority of them, is around agriculture.  They have 23 goats, 2 pigs and some chickens, and sell the products to the farmer’s markets and food stores and restaurants in the area. They also have grapevines and orchards like plums and persimmons. As for seasonal veggies, Dila plants mostly red and white cabbage, leeks, spinach, tomatoes and onions.  Their earnings are generated by the sales of baby goats and piglets and income Vlash receives from his work as a road maintenance guy. 

Vlash is seeking your financial help to pay for the pension contribution of farmers.

loans.use: to pay for the farmer's pension contribution

loans.name: Tala

texts.en: Tala is a maize farmer from Kwankwani village in Kaduna state. Before she became a Babban Gona member, Tala would have had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest, in order to cater for her immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Tala can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest time. Tala, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to provide food and clothing for her family, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in her community.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest time.

When asked about his goals, Abdullahi expressed a desire to use the extra income to provide his family with food and clothing, and in the long run, make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: To buy food and clothing thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Nubia Carolina

texts.es:
Nubia se caracteriza por ser una joven responsable,con mucho espíritu de superación, el propósito por el cual Nubia decidio estudiar psicología fue porque de esta manera le permitiría ayudar a los demás. Nubia ha tomado grandes decisiones en su vida y una de esas ha sido renunciar a su trabajo para dedicarle el tiempo completo a estudiar una maestría. Nubia una joven de 24 años cuenta con el apoyo de su familia quienes han aceptado todas las decisiones que Nubia ha hecho. 
Nubia solicita el crédito para el pago de una maestría en salud mental y adicciones ya que al estudiarla le estará abriendo puertas más grandes, así como mayores ofertas de trabajo.  Para Nubia estudiar esa maestría será una gran oportunidad para su proyección profesional ya que le  permitirá culminar sus estudios académicos, logrando así una mejor calidad de vida y a la vez autor realizarme como profesional y persona. Como planes futuros Nubia piensa Seguir estudiando, mejorar sus actitudes y aptitudes. Formar un hogar y sobre todo disfrutar lo que hará para beneficio personal y familiar.
texts.en:
Nubia is known for being a responsible young woman with a great spirit for self-improvement.  Nubia’s plan, for which she decided to study psychology, was to allow her to help others.  Nubia has made big decisions in her life, and one of them has been to quit her job in order to study for her master’s degree full time.  Nubia, age 24, has her family’s support.  They have accepted all of the decisions that Nubia has made.

Nubia is requesting the loan to pay for her master’s in mental health and other courses that, upon taking them, will open bigger doors like more work offers.

For Nubia, studying for this masters will be a big opportunity in her professional projection because it will allow her to complete her academic studies.  This way she will be achieving a better quality of life.  “At the same time I will be fulfilling myself as a professional and as a person.”

Nubia’s plans for the future are to continue studying, to improve her attitudes and aptitudes, and to start her own home.  Above all, she plans to enjoy what she will be doing for her personal and familial benefit.

loans.use: to pay for her master’s in mental health and other courses.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to connect to Haiti's first prepay microgrid

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase video equipment and office supplies

loans.name: Maritess

texts.en: Maritess engages in farming. She grows and sells rice. Aside from that, she also raises and sells hogs. She is a 39-year-old married woman with 4 children. Her oldest child is 19 and the youngest is 2. She lives in Mcarthur, Leyte. She also engages in buy-and-sell business, where she sells rice on a retail basis to the people living in her community. She is asking for a loan to buy pig feed and additional rice to sell. These stocks are very essential in her buy-and-sell business. This will slowly help improve her day to day living. Thus, she could now provide a proper diet to her whole family. Maritess dreams to expand her business to make it productive and profitable in order to have a sustainable livelihood and also to be able to support the needs of her growing children.

loans.use: to buy pig feed and additional rice to sell

loans.use: to connect to Haiti's first prepay microgrid

loans.use: To pay for his children's school fees and uniforms thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Julien

texts.en:
Julien is 37 years old. He is married with 3 children aged between 6 months and 7 years old, two of them whom go to school. He is a farmer and has been farming for 19 years now. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to buy maize fertilizers for sale. The profits from the business will be used to improve his standards of living.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy maize fertilizers for sale.

loans.name: Solidario Estela De San Pedro Group

texts.es: Solidario Estela de San Pedro La encargada de este grupo es la señora Blanca Estela quien se dedica a la venta de cosméticos en general como cremas, litros de champo, desodorantes, estuches de lociones para damas, caballeros y niños, estuches de talcos, colonias, lápiz labiales, calzado por catálogo y sabanas, cubrecamas, colchas de catálogo desde hace 12 años. Es vendedora ambulante y está muy contenta con el negocio que Dios le ha regalado.  Su esposo la ayuda y la apoya en todo y sus hijas cada una en su diferente trabajo la ayudan a vender. Su sueño es tener un lugar específico en el mercado  para poder vender sus productos y no tener que caminar tanto.  Tiene varios pedidos de cremas, desodorantes, estuches de colonias, sabanas y colchas en otras tiendas donde entrega pero el producto que tiene en casa no le es suficiente por tal motivo necesita un préstamo para poder ir a la tienda a comprar con dinero en mano las cosas que le hacen falta y no desaprovechar las ventas que tiene.
texts.en:
Blanca Estela is in charge of the Estela de San Pedro communal bank.  She has been selling general cosmetics like creams; liters of shampoo; deodorants; lotion packages for women, men, and children; packages of talcum powder; cologne; lipstick; shoes by catalog; and sheets, bedspreads, and quilts by catalog for 12 years.  She is an itinerant salesperson, and she is very happy with the business that God has given her.

Her husband helps her and supports her in everything.  Each one of her daughters has a different job, and they help her sell.

Her dream is to have a specific place at the market in order to be able to sell her products and not have to walk so much.

She has various orders for creams, deodorants, cologne sets, sheets, and quilts from other stores where she delivers her products.  However, she does not have enough products at home.  That is why she needs a loan to be able to go to the store and buy, with money in hand, the things that she does not have and not lose the sales that she has.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics to sell.

loans.name: Solidario Maria Del Rosario Group

texts.es: Solidario Maria del Rosario La encargada de este agrupo es la señora Brenda Leticia quien tiene una tortillería desde hace 10 años, la cual la tiene ubicada en la calle principal del mercado del pueblo. Cuenta con el apoyo incondicional de su esposo y el amor incomparable de sus tres hijos. Su sueño es tener un lugar más grande con mucho espacio,  para atender mejor a sus clientes y no tenerlos parados en la calle. El quintal de maíz está a punto de subir por las fechas de fin de año y necesita comprar varios quintales para no comprar más adelante que se pone muy caro.  El dinero que tiene no le alcanza y por tal razón necesita un préstamo para poder cancelar el pedido que ya hizo, para aprovechar los precios bajos que aún le ofrecen.
texts.en: Solidario Maria del Rosario group - the leader of this group is Brenda Leticia who has had a tortilla making business for 10 years, which she has located on the main street of the town's market. She has the unconditional support of her husband and incomparable love of her three children. Her dream is to have a much larger retail space with a lot of room to serve her customers better and not have them standing in the street. The price of a quintal [approximately 100 pounds] of corn is about to rise due to it being the end of the year and she needs to purchase several quintales to not buy them later when they are very expensive. The money that she has isn't enough and for this reason she needs a loan to be able to pay for the order that she has already made, to take advantage of the low prices that they still offer.

loans.use: to purchase corn to sell.

loans.name: Irma

texts.en:
Irma is a 29-year-old single woman from Rustavi city. She lives alone and earns a living with the help of private activity. In particular, she transfers goods from the capital and sells in her community with increased prices. Irma has her own loyal customers and generates approximately 200 GEL monthly. In order to make her business more profitable and expand the variety of products, Irma needs financial support. 

The start up program that is a joint initiative between Kiva and Credo enables people like Irma to start or re-start their own activities. Irma was approved for the loan of 1,800 USD, which she plans to use for purchasing all needed equipment for shop, also for stock of clothing and bags and to be able to open in a good location in the town. She has already found the suitable space for her dream shop and will pay a monthly amount for renting. She relies on the goodwill of Kiva lenders to give help for her business development.  

Irma is a really motivated and hardworking person, who has a great desire to make a good lifestyle for herself and develop her trading business. She awaits your support.

loans.use: To expand her trading business and open a shop

loans.name: Nazibrola

texts.en:
Nazibrola is a 31-year-old housekeeper, from small village Nosiri. She has seven family members, and the employed persons in the family are her husband and brother-in-law. They both have a fixed salary of 400 GEL. Nazibrola is involved in agricultural activity, in particular she takes care of milk cow and pigs and generates income from selling milk products and pigs locally. She doesn't have significant income from this activity and is eager somehow to increase the productivity. 

Nazibrola requested a loan from Credo to start a trading business. Her loan request was approved in the framework of a new joint initiative by Kiva and Credo. The startup loan program envisages provisions for business startups and re-startup credits with soft conditions for the country's rural poor, who, regarded as "high risk borrowers" because of their low income, do not have access to credit products. With the received credit, Nazibrola will purchase stock of various kinds of clothing. She will start trading and get private orders also. 

The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva startup loan, will give Nazibrola a chance to increase her contribution to the family's welfare and make a better lifestyle for her children.

loans.use: To start a trading business and improve her family's living condition

loans.name: Francisco

texts.en: Francisco decided to invest in a Sistema Biobolsa biodigester in order to produce his own energy and organic fertilizer using manure from his cows and sheep. He used to buy expensive LP gas and chemical fertilizers, which were significantly reducing his available income and damaging the environment. From now on, he will input his animals' waste in the biodigester, treating the manure and transforming it into methane-rich biogas to cook and heat water in the house, as well as nutrient-rich fertilizer to spread on his field to increase the yield of his corn in a natural way. With his savings, he plans to improve the infrastructure around his farm to be ready for future expansions. (This loan represents 20% of the total cost of the biodigester, the remaining part being covered by a government subsidy.)

loans.use: to purchase a Sistema Biobolsa waste-to-energy biodigester.

loans.name: Alh. Usaini

texts.en: Alh. Usaini is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Alh. Usaini joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Abubakar and Hussaini.  Before he became a Babban Gona member, Alh. Usaini would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Alh. Usaini can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Alh. Usaini  spoke of his intention to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to ensure his children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: To pay for his children's school fees and uniforms thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Ishaku

texts.en:

Before he became a Babban Gona member, Ishaku would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Ishaku can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

When asked, Ishaku  spoke of his  ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to ensure other members of his community are lifted out of poverty.

loans.use: To pay for children's school fees and uniforms, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Agustina

texts.en:
Agustina grew up on the farm where she currently lives, and she is aware that the daily expenses for energy and chemical fertilizers can become a strong weight for the family's finances. She decided to invest in a Sistema Biobolsa biodigester in order to displace these costly and unsustainable energy and fertilizer sources to produce her own. She wants to take advantage of her animals' manure and the methane it contains to cook and heat water with biogas produced inside the biodigester. She is also looking forward to spreading the organic and nutrient-rich fertilizer, which is treated by the bacteria in the biodigester, on her field to increase the yield of her crops in a natural way. 

Not only will Agustina save money, she will also protect her environment and turn her farm into a cleaner and more comfortable place to live. With her savings, she plans to purchase more tools and seeds to expand her production of vegetables, and in the longer term she would like to expand the farm for her animals to have more space.

This loan represents 20% of the total cost of the biodigester, the remaining part being covered by a government subsidy.

loans.use: to invest in a 10 m3 waste-to-energy biodigester.

loans.name: Dúo Luisa Alejandra Group

texts.es: Dúo Luisa Alejandra, este grupo lo integra la señora Sara Magdalena de 38 años de edad, ella se dedica a la venta de cosméticos desde hace varios años, en esta oportunidad ella está solicitando este crédito para la compra de cosméticos para la venta ya que en esta temporada es cuando sus clientes le hacen pedidos por mayor y no tiene el capital para invertir.
texts.en: Luisa Alejandra group - this group was formed by Sara Magdalena, 38 years old, who has sold cosmetics for some years. In this opportunity, she is asking for this loan to purchase cosmetics to sell since it is the season when her customers make orders in bulk and she doesn't have the capital to invest.

loans.use: to purchase cosmetics to sell.

loans.name: Jorge

texts.en:
Jorge is a Mexican farmer who owns several cows, sheep and poultry. He used to pile their waste up outside the farm, contributing to the contamination of underground water sources, the emission of greenhouse gases and attracting swarms of flies. By purchasing his biodigester, he will not only be able to displace the expensive and unsustainable fossil fuel based LP gas and chemical fertilizers to reduce his operating costs, but he will also improve his carbon footprint. 

The biogas and fertilizer produced in the biodigester from his animals' manure will allow him to take advantage of the resources available on his farm to cook and heat water in the house. The yield of his crops will increase in a natural way as he spreads the nutrient-rich and organic fertilizer on the field. The Sistema Biobolsa biodigester will allow him to save money while turning his farm in an increasingly self-sufficient and sustainable place.
This loan represents 23% of the total cost of the biodigester, the remaining part being covered by a government subsidy.

loans.use: to invest in an 8 m3 Sistema Biobolsa biodigester.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to connect to Haiti's first pre-pay solar-powered microgrid

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to connect to Haiti's first pre-pay solar-powered microgrid

loans.name: Matilda

texts.en:
Matilda is 32 years old. She is married to Julius, and together, they have been blessed with two children of 9 and 6 years.

Matilda is a tailor, a business she has done for the last 10 years, earning a monthly income of 30,000 KES.
 
Matilda has requested her first loan with VisionFund Kenya of 10,000 KES, which she will use to add stock of new textiles.

With the anticipated profits, Matilda will be able to improve her lifestyle.

Her hope and dream for the future is to be able to support her family and children.

loans.use: to buy stock of new textiles

loans.name: Ileen

texts.en:
Tucked away in the countryside near the Kabiyet, Eldoret area of Kenya is a jobless mum-turned farmer named Ileen and her  beautiful angel named Rency. She is a hardworking mum and aggressive with the principle of truth on her lips; she is honest and faithful to what she does and what she says. 

Kabiyet lies in a valley. In this valley are a people who, in their totality, constitute wrenching statistics. Hardcore poverty pervades every homestead yet every day when you look beyond the numbers, you will see a sea of people: a sea of about 2,000 bright, vibrant, open faces, searching and yearning for the opportunity to live a life of dignity and respect. They have the conviction that it’s possible. They are like the bones in the “valley of dry bones” that required only a breath to spring back to life. 

Armed with this conviction, Ileen has kept hope and has been toiling on her farm for the past five years. Her primary source of income is milk, crops and some vegetables that she plants. She also engages in a personal business and has been able to earn a handsome profit from the venture. Ileen practices agriculture with a difference, employing youthful energy, enthusiasm and knowledge from the many agricultural training courses she has been attending to broaden her skills. 

Although she earns handsome profits from farming, Ileen faces one big challenge of poor crop production. She is kindly requesting a loan to build a greenhouse. A greenhouse provides controlled temperatures which assist in crop production. Through the loan she will double her crop production because her crops will not be affected by harsh and bad weather conditions.

Your lending will contribute greatly to the actualization of Ileen’s goal, which is to expand the greenhouse . In the future, she is also planning to introduce the zero grazing method, intensify her maize farming, and start value addition.

loans.use: To build a greenhouse

loans.name: Mwana-Idi

texts.en:
Mwana-idi is a married woman. She has six children. She describes herself to be committed. She operates a retail business where she sells fish (omena type). She has been involved in this business for three years. Her business is located in an area suitable for the business and her primary customers are the general public. 

Mwana-idi will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more stock of omena fish. She hopes that in the future, she will have a successful business. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of omena fish

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase construction supplies and carpentering materials to build other rooms inside her house to make it spacious.

loans.name: Justine

texts.en:
Justine is a married man. He has two children. He describes himself to be determined. He operates a retail business where he sells charcoal. He has been involved in this business for three years. His business is located in a good area and his primary customers are of all types. 

Justine describes his biggest business challenge to be lack of finances. He will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more stock of charcoal. His business goal is to be a supplier within five years. He hopes that in the future, he will have a successful life.

loans.use: to buy more stock of charcoal

loans.name: Priscillah

texts.en:
Priscillah is a female Kiva borrower. She describes herself to be industrious. She operates a retail business where she sells suitcases, cups, glasses, vacuum flasks, plates and other household items. She has been involved in this business for 11 years. Her business is located in an area with potential, and her primary customers are regular. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inflation. 

She will use the 20,000 KES loan to buy more stock of cups, plates, vacuum flasks, bags and other items. Her business goal is to have a superstore within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will sustain her family. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of cups, plates, vacuum flasks, bags and other items

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is a 35-year-old married man with four children attending different schools. He deals in cattle fattening, working for 5 days a week and 8 hours a day and has been in this business since 2007.

He also deals in milk supply from which he generates an additional income to support his family. He operates in areas of Kakuuto, Kyakatuuma and Rakai and usually sells his goods to fellow traders and local people in that area.

He hopes to use the loan to expand his grazing land and also buy cows for fattening and sale. He  faces a challenge, however, of limited capital and long seasons of drought which affect his operations. He is described as an honest and hard-working man in business.

loans.use: To purchase cows

loans.name: Jay Harshiddhi Mahila Mandal Group

texts.en:
Kanchanben leads a group of four women from Wadhwan, in India’s western state of Gujarat. She is aged 31 and the mother of three school-going children. She runs a microenterprise that sells textiles that include dresses, saris, curtains, cushion covers, and bed sheets. For women in her society, respect is hard-earned. By running this small-scale business, Kanchanben is able to contribute Rs.3000 every month to the family’s income. In addition to giving her life purpose, her hard work and efforts earn the admiration and respect of everyone in her community.

She has a plan to expand the scale of her operations; with additional capital she can increase and diversify her inventory and offer products of better quality to her customers. Priorities such as her children’s education and health eat into her paltry savings, leaving little capital to expand her business. She is in search of a microloan to help her achieve her goal of doubling her monthly income within a year. 

Her group members are Ushaben, who also runs a retail textile business, Lataben, the proprietor of a neighborhood general store, and Laxmiben, who runs a microenterprise that deals with buying and selling of wood. These women are seeking a joint microloan of Rs. 100,000 that will help each of them to expand their small-scale businesses. Your loan will help Kanchanben and her group to create a better future for their families and render lessons in hard work and persistence to their children – lessons better taught by actions than by words.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks of saris, dresses, and home textiles and grow her cloth-selling microenterprise

loans.name: Saratu

texts.en: Saratu is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Saratu joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for her children: Jibo, Lawisa and Alheri.  Before she became a Babban Gona member, Saratu would have had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest, in order to cater for her immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Saratu can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest time. When asked, Saratu spoke of her ambition to use the additional income to educate her children, eventually hoping to become the most profitable farmer in her community.

loans.use: to pay for childrens school fees and uniforms, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses has a motorcycle transport business in Eldoret town and has been in the business for five years now. He is 25 years old, married, and together with his spouse has been blessed with one child. 

He will use this loan to service his motorcycle by buying new spare parts. He will also buy fuel for his motorcycle as this will enable him to serve more customers and make more income. He will use the anticipated profits to buy food for his family. 

This is his third loan from VisionFund Kenya and in future he hopes to have a prosperous business and improve his family's living standard.

loans.use: To buy fuel and new spare parts for his motorcycle.

loans.name: Amina Yosiya

texts.en: Amina Yosiya is a maize farmer from Sarkin Dawa village in Kaduna state. Before she became a Babban Gona member, Amina Yosiya would have had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest, in order to cater for her immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Amina Yosiya can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest time. Amina Yosiya, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to provide food and clothing for her family, and hopes to ensure other members of her community are lifted out of poverty.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest time.

loans.name: Linet

texts.en:
Linet is a Kiva borrower. She has four children. She describes herself to be committed. She operates a retail business where she sells firewood. She has been involved in this business for six years. Her business is located in a suitable area. She describes her biggest business challenge to be transportation costs. 

She will use the 20,000 KES loan to buy more stock of firewood. Her business goal is to expand further within five years. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of firewood

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is married and has two children. He operates a tailoring shop where he makes clothes, which he has been doing for three years. His business is located in a good area and his primary customers are the general public. He describes his biggest business challenge to be lack of enough working capital. 

Francis requested his second loan from SMEP Microfinance Bank for 10,000 KES, which he will use to buy more stock of tailoring materials. His business goal is to expand within five years.

loans.use: to purchase tailoring materials

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Caroline is a married woman. She has 2 children. She describes herself to be determined. She operates a retail business where she sells bags, suitcases, metal boxes, etc.. She has been involved in this business for 2 years. 

Her business is located in a marketable place and her primary customers are the general public. She describes her biggest business challenge to be price fluctuations. 

She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more stock of bags, metal boxes and other items. Her business goal is to have a larger store within 5 years. She hopes that in the future she will expand her business and educate her children. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of bags, metal boxes and other items.

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa is a widowed woman. She has 4 children. She describes herself to be determined. She operates a brick making business. She has been involved in this business for 3 years. 

Her business is located in a marketable place and her primary customers are house builders. She describes her biggest business challenge to be bad weather. 

She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy soil and firewood for making the bricks. Her business goal is to have a large brick making firm within 5 years. She hopes that in the future she will expand her business and create employment. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy soil and firewood for making bricks.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy spare parts to service his motorcycle.

loans.name: Millicent

texts.en:
Millicent is a married woman. She has 5 children. She describes herself to be God fearing. She operates a retail shop where she sells cereals. She has been involved in this business for 3 years. Her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are the general public. 

She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more stock of cereals. Her business goal is to have a wholesale business within 5 years. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of cereals.

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius is a married man. He has 2 children. He describes himself to be ambitious. He operates a retail business where he sells timber. He has been involved in this business for 2 years. 

His business is located in a competitive location and his primary customers are the general public. He describes his biggest business challenge to be financial constraints. 

He will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more stock of timber. His business goal is to have a bigger store within 5 years. He hopes that in the future, he will have a better life and increased profits. This is his first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of timber.

loans.name: Dieu Benit 2 (2) Group

texts.en:
Irma is 53 years old and continues to take care of her younger sister and two younger brothers. For the last 19 years, Irma has run her own business selling groceries and other miscellaneous items in Brazzaville, the Republic of Congo. Irma has a small shop in front of her house where she sells cooking oil, soap, sugar, rice and other miscellaneous items. In order to grow her business, Irma joined HOPE Congo in 2013 and became part of the community bank group DIEU BENIT 2 (2). 

She would like to take out a loan of 500,000 CFA to continue to invest in her business. With this money, Irma will be able to purchase additional sacks of sugar and rice to divide up into smaller portions to sell. She will also buy salted fish, soap, and beans to add to her stock. Being a part of DIEU BENIT 2 (2) has helped Irma to combat the constant fluctuations in market prices now that she is able to purchase all her goods at once. Irma brings in customers by welcoming people with open arms so that people feel at ease in her shop. 

In the future Irma hopes that her business will become stable enough that she will be able to travel to other countries and launch herself into commerce. Irma dreams of traveling to Cotonou, Benin to purchase appliances and clothes for resale in Brazzaville, where such items are unavailable. For herself and her family, Irma hopes to eventually build her own house with the profits from her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of sugar and rice, and salted fish, soap, and beans for her shop

loans.name: Charity

texts.en:
Hello, lenders! Meet Charity from Kapsowar, Kenya. Kapsowar is an area where the earth is red and smells fresh from the rain. The trees are lush and tiny, matchbox-like; mud brick houses with tin roofs line either side of the dirt roads. 

Charity is happily married, and she and her husband have been blessed with two lovely children. For the past five years Charity has been involved in mixed farming, and her primary sources of income have been milk, eggs, vegetables, and some personal business she engages in to make extra cash. 

She has been able to provide nutritious food for her family. She passionately loves dairy farming. “Cows are part of me. I love cows, I walk cows, I sleep cows, I eat cows,” she says. The village women call her Mrs.Cow. 

Charity sells milk to her neighbors and to the local market, but the main challenge she faces is the lack of a proper fence in her compound. Her cows have been straying to neighbors' farms and this has been causing a lot of animosity among the neighbors. She has been forced to pay for the damages caused by her cows. 

She is kindly seeking a loan to buy barbed wire. With this loan she will have control over her cows grazing and she will save the money that she used to spend in paying for damages.

loans.use: To buy barbed wire.

loans.name: Dieu Benit 2 (1) Group

texts.en:
Berthe is a married mother of five, and has run her own businesses to support her family for as long as she can remember. With her last two children finishing school, Berthe seeks to expand her business to keep supporting them and eventually have enough savings to achieve her lifelong dream of building her own home. Berthe currently runs a frozen meat business, selling frozen chicken, pork and beef. On the side, she also sells pagne, traditional Congolese fabric.

In 2013, in order to grow her business, Berthe joined HOPE Congo and became a member of the community bank group DIEU BENIT 2 (1). Leading a subgroup of 12 other micro-entrepreneurs from Brazzaville, the Republic of Congo, Berthe is now on her fourth loan cycle with HOPE Congo. Back when she first started in 2013, Berthe took out a small loan of 250,000 CFA. Now, two years later, Berthe would like to take out a loan of 550,000 CFA. With this money, Berthe will be able to place her next bulk order of pagne to sell individually in Brazzaville, as well as purchase additional frozen meat.

Despite the constant challenges of not having a stable source of power, Berthe hopes to purchase a generator in the future. One day she dreams of having her own cold storage room to keep all of her frozen meat in.

loans.use: to purchase additional frozen meat and relaunch her fabric business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane is a hard working lady aged 38 years from Kiterezi in Nyakayojo division, Rwampala in the Mbarara district of Uganda. She got married at the early age of 17 years old. They stayed together for some years and produced 4 children. Later her hudband became very violent to the extent that he was beating her. Fearing for her dear life, she decided to divorce her husband and then she went with the children. Life became difficult as she had no source of income and then, Jane decided to start up a business of selling groceries with the loan she got from Ugafode. She later saved some money and built a house for her family. She is now requesting for a loan of 3,000,000 UGX to complete her house such that the burden of renting will be lifted from her.

loans.use: to buy building materials

loans.name: Bello

texts.en: Bello is a maize farmer from Badamasi village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Bello would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, in order to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Bello can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest time. Bello, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to provide food and clothing for his family, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Natividad Adan

texts.es: Natividad de 55 años de edad habita en vivienda propia junto a su grupo familiar. Él se gana la vida con su negocio de una tienda de productos básicos como: pan dulce, golosinas, arroz, azúcar, café, leche en polvo, frijoles, papel higiénico, champú, detergente, jabón, etc., desde hace 20 años por lo que cuenta con una buena cantidad de clientes manteniendo la estabilidad económica de su hogar. Natividad desea construir un corredor en su vivienda y para ello solicita un crédito a FUSAI para invertir en: lámina galvanizada, madera, clavos, cemento, arena, y grava para construir un corredor en su vivienda.
texts.en:
Natividad is 55 years old and lives in his own house together with his family. He makes his living with his store selling basic products like pastries, sweets, rice, sugar, coffee, milk powder, beans, toilet paper, shampoo, detergent, soap, etc. He has been doing this for 20 years so he has a good number of clients to keep the household economy stable.

Natividad wants to build a veranda on his house so he is requesting a loan from FUSAI to invest in galvanized laminate, wood, nails, cement, sand and gravel to construct a veranda on his house.

loans.use: to invest in galvanized laminate, wood, nails, cement, sand, gravel to construct a veranda on his house.

loans.name: Francisco

texts.es: Francisco tiene 54 años de edad y habita en vivienda propia junto a su compañera de vida y sus 5 hijos de 18, 17, 15, 8 y 6 años de edad. Él se esfuerza para poder llevarle la economía de su hogar con su trabajo de mecánico de obra de banco en el cual elabora estructuras metálicas. Francisco desea construir un muro alrededor de su vivienda ya que teme que pueda ocurrir un accidente por la tierra que esta alrededor, además desea construir cunetas para que en época de lluvia no se mine la tierra, por lo que solicita un crédito a FUSAI para invertir en: cemento, arena, grava, ladrillo y hierro para construir un muro y una cuneta alrededor de su vivienda.
texts.en: Francisco is 54 years old and lives in his own house with his wife and his 5 children, who are 18, 17, 15, 8 and 6 years old.  He strives to support his home with his work as a welding mechanic, where he makes metallic structures.  Francisco wants to construct a wall around his home, as he fears that an accident could occur on the surrounding land.  He also wants to build curbs so that the rain does not wash away the land during the rainy season.
